thread.title: Brisbane weather: City records hottest January on record | The Courier-Mail
thread.title_full: Brisbane weather: City records hottest January on record | The Courier-Mail

title: Brisbane weather: City records hottest January on record | The Courier-Mail
text:
No let-up in sight 
BRISBANE has sweltered through its hottest January on record. 
The Bureau of Meteorology today released data showing the city averaged 27.2C, well above the mean temperature for the month of 25.4C and breaking the previous record of 27C set in 2004. 
The city also recorded its hottest January average minimum with 23C, breaking the 22.8C recorded in 1973. It was also the highest average minimum for any month. 
And Brisbane sweltered through its equal hottest overnight minimum of 28C on January 21, equalling the record set in 1940 and repeated in 2004. US AL: Scientist Captures Record Low Levels of Arctic Sea Ice January 29 0:29 
Global sea ice levels are at a record low as temperatures recorded at the North Pole in November and December were 10 degrees warmer than the average. Disconcerting footage by filmed by a scientist for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration on January 29 illustrated the point. Chelsea Thompson was on her way to Barrow, Alaska, when she captured the thin ice cover over the Arctic ocean. Credit: Twitter/ArcticAirDoctor via Storyful February 1st 2017 /video/video.news.com.au/News/ US AL: Scientist Captures Record Low Levels of Arctic Sea Ice January 29 
Aside from Brisbane, 18 other Queensland “hot spots” broke records for their January average temperature, including Surat with 30.6C, Cunnamulla post office with 33.4C and Taroom post office with 30.3C. 
Maryborough reached the highest January temperature at 39.6C on January 21, almost 9C above the January average and its warmest day in 61 years. 
It also experienced a record 14 days in January with a max temperature equal to or above 35C. 
In the Brisbane region, the hottest day was recorded at Amberley on January 14, a staggering 38.7C. 
Thunderstorms earlier in the month also brought higher-than-average rainfall in Brisbane and the western suburbs, while bayside locations recorded half their January average. 
Farmers around the Wide Bay and Burnett regions got little reprieve, with below-average rain. 
The Bureau of Meteorology observed that Queensland had experienced an “unusually quiet tropical cyclone season to date, with no tropical cyclones” forming “so far.”
